feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 8:37AM PST until December 2 at 3:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM PST this afternoon. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Kalamazoo County.
* WHEN...Until 1 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Visibility and road conditions may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening commute.

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued December 2 at 7:55AM PST until December 2 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures of 33 to 36 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...South Central Oregon Coast, including all coastal areas from Port Orford north to around Reedsport as well as the Coquille Valley.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM PST this morning.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A few of the typically colder locations could fall to freezing.

cap:parameter.value: FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM PST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued December 2 at 7:55AM PST until December 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A ridge of high pressure will lead to a strong inversion and stagnant air conditions near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants. This could worsen air quality over time.
* WHERE...Valley locations across southern Oregon. West of the Cascades, this includes the Umpqua, Illinois, Applegate, and Rogue valleys, including Grants Pass, Sunny Valley, Galice, Murphy, Selma, Cave Junction and O'Briend. East of the Cascades, this includes Klamath Falls, Sprague River, Chiloquin, Chemult, Silver Lake, Paisley, and surrounding areas.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Douglas County; Eastern Curry County and Josephine County; Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County; Central and Eastern Lake County

cap:parameter.value: AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued December 2 at 7:55AM PST until December 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures will continue warming this morning, allowing the cold weather advisory to expire. A ridge of high pressure will lead to a strong inversion and stagnant air conditions near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants. This could worsen air quality over time.
* WHERE...For the Air Stagnation Advisory, the Rogue, Applegate and Sams valleys in Jackson County, including Medford, Talent, Phoenix, Eagle Point, Central Point, Jacksonville, Applegate and Shady Cove.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.

cap:parameter.value: AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST WEDNESDAY... ...COLD WEATHER ADVISORY WILL EXPIRE AT 8 AM PST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 10:21AM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 3 and 6 inches in the northern portion of the county, dropping off to 1 to 3 inches in the central and southern portions of the county.
* WHERE...Geauga County.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Plan on slippery road conditions with slower travel likely. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow rates may reach 1 inch per hour at times within snow bands across the northern portion of the county.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Ashtabula Inland, Ashtabula Lakeshore, and Lake Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 10:21AM EST until December 3 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 6 and 15 inches for much of the county. Locally higher amounts up to 20 inches is possible in far northeastern Erie County where a persistent Lake Huron connection is expected to persist.
* WHERE...Northern Erie and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy lake effect snow remains possible through Tuesday afternoon, although overall snowfall rates should be less intense with rates near 1 inch per hour possible in the heaviest bands. A Lake Huron connection is expected to persist and impact the far northeastern portion of Erie County where locally higher amounts are possible.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:35AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 30 hours, portions of the southern panhandle have seen heavy rain with rainfall accumulations of over 1 inch, ranging to over 7 inches in parts of Ketchikan.
Heavy rain is expected to continue through Monday with another 1.5 to 3.5 inches, more at higher elevation, through 3 PM Monday.
Runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain, particularly in areas where the ground froze over the last week. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for flashy creeks to spike up. Boat owners should check on their vessels.
After a short-lived lull in the rain Monday night, another round of moderate to heavy rain is expected for Tuesday. 24 hour rainfall totals on Tuesday are expected to be 1 to 3 inches across the south.
Each round of heavy rain will have strong winds with gusts greater than 40 mph likely.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAIN AND STRONG WIND EXPECTED TO CONTINUE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:35AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Snow is changing over to rain through the area today. A significant snow pack exists from the resent storm. Once the snow completely changes over to rain, an extended period of rain on snow is expected with rainfall continuing through Tuesday.
The rain will make snow removal difficult due to higher water content making the snow heavier. Areas of compact snow will become very slippery. There could also be areas of ponding of water due to blocked culverts or drains.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: RAIN ON SNOW WILL CREATE SLIPPERY CONDITIONS

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued December 2 at 9:02AM EST until December 3 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 30 expected.
* WHERE...In Florida, Coastal Nassau and Eastern Marion Counties. In Georgia, Coastal Camden and Coastal Glynn Counties.
* WHEN...From 1 AM to 9 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Appropriate action should be taken to ensure tender vegetation and outdoor pets have adequate protection from the cold temperatures. Young children, the elderly and the homeless are especially vulnerable to the cold. Take measures to protect them.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Nassau; Eastern Marion; Coastal Glynn; Coastal Camden

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 8:00AM CST by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary: Light snow continues to fall over much of southeast Iowa, northeast Missouri, and west central Illinois this morning, with light snow accumulations that are generally an inch or less. The main accumulating snow is expected to end by noon, though flurries may persist longer. Despite these light snow amounts, roadways may become snow covered and slick, resulting in the first winter weather driving conditions of this winter season for some locations. This will impact the morning commute, so allow for extra time to reach your destination and use extra caution if traveling this morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Buchanan; Benton; Linn; Iowa; Johnson; Cedar; Muscatine; Scott; Keokuk; Washington; Louisa; Jefferson; Henry; Des Moines; Van Buren; Lee; Rock Island; Henry; Mercer; Henderson; Warren; Hancock; McDonough; Scotland; Clark

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 4:39AM AKST until December 4 at 5:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total ice accumulations of a glaze up to one tenth of an inch and snow accumulations of up to two inches. North winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...From 3 PM this afternoon to 5 PM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation will bring chances for freezing rain. The first round, beginning this afternoon, will bring chances for a trace to a few hundredths of an inch of ice mixed in with light snow. Another round of precipitation Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday brings higher chances and greater amounts of freezing rain. The best chances for freezing rain and greatest accumulation will occur along a line roughly from Dillingham north through Koliganek, in the area east of the Ahklun Mountains. However, at least a glaze of ice is possible across most of the area. Precipitation will switch to rain from east to west on Wednesday as winds shift out of the southeast.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 3 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 5 PM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued December 2 at 4:23AM AKST until December 2 at 9:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW CONTINUES INTO MONDAY...
Heavy snow continues for the Haines area with warm temperatures aloft over Juneau and Gustavus transitioning precipitation type to a wintery mix including freezing rain. The transition to rain has reached Angoon and Pelican with the rain- snow line slowly moving north through Monday morning.
* WHAT...Heavy wet snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 5 inches.
* WHERE...City of Hyder.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM AKST this morning.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...A brief period of freezing rain is likely before the snow fully transitions to rain Monday morning.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM AKST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued December 2 at 4:23AM AKST until December 2 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW CONTINUES INTO MONDAY...
Heavy snow continues for the Haines area with warm temperatures aloft over Juneau and Gustavus transitioning precipitation type to a wintery mix including freezing rain. The transition to rain has reached Angoon and Pelican with the rain- snow line slowly moving north through Monday morning.
* WHAT...Heavy mixed precipitation. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches and ice accumulations of around one tenth of an inch.
* WHERE...Gustavus.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST today.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult. Heavy wet snow will be difficult to manage due to high water content.
* ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...A brief period of freezing rain is likely before the snow fully transitions to rain early Monday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKST TODAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 4:02AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: Bands of snowfall across the Pribilof Islands could become heavier as the back side of a strong low pressure system moves across the Bering Sea through Tuesday afternoon. Due to the showery nature of these snow bands, the exact timing and intensity could vary. Additionally, visibility may be reduced to one quarter mile at times with gusty east winds up to 35 mph, becoming southeast this afternoon. Snowfall rates and winds may diminish as early as Monday night, however there is potential for hazardous conditions to last through Tuesday afternoon.

cap:parameter.value: PERIODS OF HEAVY SNOWFALL AND BLOWING SNOW POSSIBLE FOR THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:56AM CST by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Another upper level disturbance will impact the region today, with the potential of producing a light snowfall with accumulations of a dusting and up to an inch possibly in isolated locales.
Snow is expected to begin in Illinois and parts of southeast Missouri this morning, and move into southwest Indiana and western Kentucky by this afternoon.
Allow a little extra time and drive carefully just in case temperatures are near or below freezing when moisture makes contact with the road surface. Stay abreast of the latest updates and forecasts for any changes to this system.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson; Wayne; Edwards; Wabash; Perry; Franklin; Hamilton; White; Jackson; Williamson; Saline; Gallatin; Union; Johnson; Pope; Hardin; Alexander; Pulaski; Massac; Gibson; Pike; Posey; Vanderburgh; Warrick; Spencer; Carlisle; Ballard; McCracken; Graves; Livingston; Marshall; Calloway; Crittenden; Lyon; Trigg; Caldwell; Union; Webster; Hopkins; Christian; Henderson; Daviess; McLean; Muhlenberg; Todd; Perry; Cape Girardeau

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 1:38AM PST until December 3 at 12:00PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor tidal overflow expected.
* WHERE...Beaches of San Diego County and Orange County.
* WHEN...This morning through Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Minor tidal overflow during astronomical high tides of around 6 feet each morning could inundate low lying locations, including parking lots. At highest risk are Imperial Beach, La Jolla Shores, Del Mar, Cardiff, Newport Beach, Sunset Beach and Seal Beach.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Time and height of highest tides each day:
Newport Beach - Today: 6.10 feet at 841 AM.
Newport Beach - Tuesday: 6.01 feet at 916 AM.
La Jolla - Today: 6.04 feet at 837 AM.
La Jolla - Tuesday: 5.96 feet at 912 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Diego County Coastal Areas; Orange County Coastal

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 3:11AM EST until December 3 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A strong, southward-flowing longshore current is forecast to develop at all central Florida Atlantic beaches today, along with a moderate risk for dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Coastal Volusia, Coastal Brevard, Coastal Indian River, Coastal Saint Lucie, and Coastal Martin counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...The southward-flowing current could pull swimmers into deeper water, making them more susceptible to dangerous rip currents. This will also generate strong rip currents near piers, jetties, and reefs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Coastal Martin; Mainland Northern Brevard; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 2:44AM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Snow will develop across southwest Virginia late this afternoon and tonight. Light snow accumulation of a dusting to one-half inch is possible across lower elevations. Locally higher amounts of 1 to 2 inches of snow accumulation will be possible across higher elevations above 2500 feet.
Cold temperatures will remain across the Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachians early this week. Wind chills will drop into the single digits to near zero across the higher elevations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Be prepared for the possibilty of ice and snow covered roadways.

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Expected Across Mountains of Southwest Virginia Tonight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 2:44AM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Light snow will develop across the region this evening and tonight. Light snow accumulation of a dusting to one-half inch is possible. Localized higher amounts of 1 inch snow accumulation will be possible across the highest ridge and mountain peaks of the plateau, generally above 2500 feet.
Cold temperatures will remain across the Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachians early this week. Wind chills will drop into the single digits to near zero across the higher elevations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Be prepared for the possibilty of ice and snow covered roadways across higher terrain.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued December 2 at 3:37PM ChST until December 4 at 5:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Through late Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Building trade swell from a trade-wind surge to the east is building surf along east facing reefs, causing the risk of rip currents to become high. The trade- wind surge is expected to weaken around midweek, allowing the trade swell and surf to slowly diminish, and allowing the risk of rip currents to become moderate.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RISK OF RIP CURRENTS THROUGH LATE TUESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 1 at 8:24PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 24 hours, portions of the southern panhandle have seen snow changing to heavy rain with rainfall accumulations of over 1 inch, ranging to over 5 inches in parts of Ketchikan.
Heavy rain is expected to continue through Sunday night and Monday with another 2 to 4 inches, more at higher elevation, between 6 PM Sunday and 6 PM Monday.
Runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain, particularly in areas where the ground froze over the last week. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for flashy creeks to spike up. Boat owners should check on their vessels.
After a short-lived lull in the rain Monday night, another round of moderate to heavy rain is expected for Tuesday. 24 hour rainfall totals on Tuesday are expected to be 1 to 3 inches across the south.
Each round of heavy rain will have strong winds with gusts greater than 40 mph likely.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAIN AND STRONG WIND EXPECTED TO CONTINUE

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued December 1 at 4:59PM MST until December 2 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Dense Fog Advisory, visibility one to two miles in dense fog. For the Air Stagnation Advisory in valleys, an extended period of stagnant air, with light winds and little vertical mixing. This is due to an inversion near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants.
* WHERE...Lower Treasure Valley Zones.
* WHEN...For the Dense Fog Advisory, until 11 AM MST Monday. For the Air Stagnation Advisory, until 9 PM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems. Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous especially along Interstate 84 from Fruitland, Idaho through Huntington, Oregon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Treasure Valley; Oregon Lower Treasure Valley
